Fresh Air

My research into the physiological benefits of tree emissions

Michael Woronko
Mar 30

We’ve all been there — that certain feeling after having had spent some time outdoors. Serenity, unspoken or maybe unrealized reverence for the wilderness, a calm satisfaction, maybe a sense of eudaimonia.

Personally, I used to think this had been the end-result stemming from the flow of endorphins brought about from my strenuous runs or bikes through the woods. Fresh air is great, sure, but I didn’t think there had been anything more than that. Then, I broke my collarbone and, in doing so, had to learn how to steep myself in the wilderness without any vigorous exercise, to immerse myself in the wild in a leisurely way.

To my surprise, that same feeling cascaded through my mind — that calmness, lasting beyond my time spent on the trails and permeating into the forthcoming days. It wasn’t solely the temporal disengagement from routine living that caused this sense of tranquility, nor was it the escape or the ample time spent self-discovering and contemplating. There was something more in the air.

“The beautiful spring came; and when Nature resumes her loveliness, the human soul is apt to revive also.” — Harriet Ann Jacobs

The other day, I had snow-shoe’d my way up to a lookout of a nearby national park. Spring finally arrived a few days prior but a few feet of snow still blanketed everything in sight, evaporating as fast as it had been melting. The heat of the sun had been prolific — so much so that I could almost hear the melting snow around me and, from atop a heated boulder, I could gaze upon the valley strewn below me. Under the penetrating rays of sunshine, I could see streams of particles drifting through the air, riding atop the winds that weaved and wrapped themselves around the surrounding mountains.

Patterns and Robotics: A Complex Reality - Data Driven Investor
Hayek's famous work 'The Theory of Complex Phenomena' (Hayek, 1964) delves into the topic of complexity and asserts…www.datadriveninvestor.com

These particles, whatever they had been, were a total mystery to me.

“Somewhere between the bottom of the climb and the summit is the answer to the mystery why we climb.” — Greg Child

I’ve seen many things moving through the air before: pollen, snow, drizzle, ice, fogs, mists and dust. But never have I seen such a flurry of particles cascading around on a cloudless day whereby everything had still been covered in snow and life had yet to reclaim the wilderness from the grasps of winter. I wondered for a moment what it could be before resigning myself to the idea that it had been the doing of spring — possibly all the particles and fibers and dust that became trapped in-between layers of winter snow and ice had now been set free, swept away by the rising heat and cascading winds. 
 
These particles — they weren’t painfully obvious and couldn’t really be seen if not for the right angle, squint, and blocking out of the suns rays. In other words, one could walk around outside all day and not notice the oceanic tides of particles floating about in the air unless they were to climb to the top of a ridge and look down in the right way, against the right backdrop and focus.

This got me to thinking — there’s so much floating about that we don’t necessarily take time to consider, unless we suffer from seasonal allergies or happen to study aerobiology (airborne organisms), microbiology, etc., though we should maybe stop to consider this, because we’re inhaling an enigma.

Just because we can’t see something doesn’t mean that it doesn’t affect us — we know this already. Think of it this way — would we drink the water that drops out of an exhaust pipe? We seem to be fine breathing the air despite continual findings that gasoline does more than fuel vehicles, as its fumes have been found to also fuel aggressive neuro-behavioural tendencies. Add in the supposed carcinogens of aromatic aerosols or asphalts or any number of toxic exposures and suddenly a dramatic picture emerges.

But this is not to say we should necessarily worry about what’s floating about in the airs around us at any given time; this is, rather, about what can be gained from the airs of nature, if anything at all.

And so I formed an intention to see what it is that’s really swirling around the canopies of the forests or cascading around the peaks of mountains, motivated to discover whether or not we just so happen to be breathing cleaner air or if there’s something more being emitted from the innumerable lifeforms found in the wilderness.

“I go to nature to be soothed and healed, and to have my senses put in order.” — John Burroughs

Maybe this yarn could be spun a different way.

There must be something out there, something more that explains why so many of us are drawn into the depths of the woods or at least entranced by them from afar — why greenery and vegetation soothes our minds so effectively that it has become increasingly woven into architectonics and exterior/interior design schematics, why the Japanese have been forest bathing since the 80’s and why the German’s have an untranslatable word referring to this certain connectedness with nature.

We come from the wilderness to find ourselves in unspeakably artificial habitats on a full-time basis, and this yearning to get back to nature (at least for myself) — I’m certain it’s more than simply a sense of familiarity or some sort of predisposition. I’m positive that it’s something physiological, some sort of neuro-chemical process in the brain that accounts for this waldeinsamkeit (the German word teased a few sentences back).

If toxic fumes from cleaners, fuels, paints, bonding agents, asphalts, coolants, insulations, etc. can prove a detriment to our physiological or neurological states of being, and the emissions from vegetation have been known to purify and improve air quality, then it sounds fundamentally correct to say that the innumerable terpenes that are emitted from trees and plants can do us more good than just cleaning up the air that we breathe.

Thus, it may be worth delving deeper into these natural emissions to explore their practical potential.

I swim lakes frequently and, when I do, I’m sometimes amazed at the things I find floating atop or below the surface of the water. On one bizarre instance, in the very middle of a small lake (the lake on Google Satellite is indicated as being approximately 400 x 300 meters), I had witnessed a little white spider trotting along the surface of the water as if out for a quick stroll; how it wandered there and had not yet been eaten by a bird or fish is beyond me. But apart from arachnid-Jesus, lake water is filled to the brim with particles of all sizes that an observer wouldn’t really notice until they paid closer attention.

Sure, many of said particles are water-borne, fish danders or seaweed debris, but many more fall onto the lake like snow, floating on and below the surface of water like fine grains of sand that become glued to a canvas of glass. Water is the medium in which they become trapped, ensnared, and susceptible to realization. And so, without a doubt, as I strenuously bike or run through the woods, I’m not only inhaling mouthfuls of these compounds and emissions with each breath, but I’m inhaling even more of that which can be seen with neither naked nor lensed eye.

So what is it that I’m inhaling and is it doing me any good?

Initially, it had been difficult for me to substantiate this, as every article that I searched seemed to relate back to the purifying benefits of trees — how gases like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide are pulled into the leaf and then diffused, chemically altered and no longer a threat to human lungs.

It wasn’t until I stumbled upon an article from the Department of Environmental Conservation for the state of New York that turned me in the right direction. The article points to ongoing research which is finding that there are benefits to phytoncides in the air — airborne chemicals that plants emit to protect themselves from insects. These phytoncides are also shown to have antibacterial and anti-fungal qualities that help the respective vegetation fight disease.

“When people breathe in these chemicals, our bodies respond by increasing the number and activity of a type of white blood cell called Natural Killer cells or NK. These cells kill tumor and virus-infected cells in our bodies. In one study, increased NK activity from a 3 day, 2 night forest bathing trip lasted for more than 30 days.”

It would (or should) follow that these phytoncides contribute to the health of our immune system or somehow improve our immuno-response mechanisms. I hoped this would be the case as I meandered through the labyrinths of research. Eventually, I came to find that studies supported this idea and more so illustrated that, possibly, these natural phytochemicals function as anti-carcinogen agents.

A quick run-through for the sake of brevity:

  • Field studies from 24 forests in Japan, whereby the practice of Shinrin-Yoku (forest bathing) has been in place since the 1980s, have found that “forest environments promote lower concentrations of cortisol, lower pulse rate, lower blood pressure, greater parasympathetic nerve activity, and lower sympathetic nerve activity than do city environments”.
  • Another study, in conjunction with the two points referenced above, also found that forest bathing enhances human NK activity and expression of anti-cancer proteins.
  • In addition to the last point, research looking at the blood and urine of forest-bathers revealed long-lasting immune function: “The increased NK activity lasted for more than 30 days after the trip, suggesting that a forest bathing trip once a month would enable individuals to maintain a higher level of NK activity”
  • A separate study in the Scandinavian Journal of Forest Research looked at the potential restorative effects of simply viewing real forest landscapes in comparison to urban landscapes, with physiological and psychological data being collected on each subject four times a day: “These findings support the idea that real forest landscapes may ameliorate stress, aid autonomic nervous system relaxation and increase positive emotion, and provide important scientific evidence of forest-guided health benefits”
  • One last study to reference found that immersing subjects in a forest environment amounted to lowered blood-glucose levels: “In addition to the increased calorie consumption and improved insulin sensitivity, walking in a forest environment has other beneficial effects in decreasing blood glucose levels

Lastly, we have Alpha-Pinene — a monoterpene that’s emitted by vegetation — mainly conifers but also low-lying flora like rosemary or sage. It’s responsible for the refreshing scent that evergreens are famous for and, today, alpha-pinenes are all the rage because they’re naturally found in strains of cannabis, giving pot-advocates an array of health-touting ammunition that’s forming legitimate roots in more and more research.

Studies are increasingly recognizing the health benefits of alpha-pinenes, including their anti-cancer and anti-inflammatory properties. Modern science is slowly substantiating the use of pine oil for centuries as an anti-cancer agent in traditional Chinese medicine and the innumerable benefits of various herbs that have been a staple in countless folk-remedies.

My crawl through this rabbit hole perpetuates as I continuously encounter added motivation to venture deeper. Concepts like psycho-terratica (the trauma caused by a distance from nature), solastalgia (distress caused by environmental change) or ecoagnosy (stress over changing landscapes) capture my attention as I reinforce my own beliefs with every trek into my local national park.

Beyond physiological or psychological responses, the one thing I’m sure about is that there is an entire cornucopia of our collective interest into this subject and it is this interest in itself that convinces me of something much deeper at play between ourselves and the fresh airs of nature.
